title: The First Historical References
description: The earliest historical references to the hill come from the Satavahana dynasty. Inscriptions from the Nashik caves, specifically the Prashasti of Pulumavi, mention 'Srisaila' or 'Setagiri,' indicating the site was already a recognized landmark and pilgrimage destination. During this era, the site was likely an open-air natural shrine—a Swayambhu Linga worshipped by forest-dwelling tribes.

title: The Buddhist Connection
description: The Ikshvaku kings ruled from nearby Vijayapuri (Nagarjunakonda). While Ikshvaku queens patronized Buddhism (evident from Nagarjunakonda ruins), the kings were staunch Shaivites who made endowments to the Srisailam shrine. The temple remained a forest sanctuary during this period, but began receiving royal attention.

title: The First Stone Structures
description: The Badami and Kalyani Chalukyas (7th-11th centuries) were instrumental in structural developments. King Pulakeshin II is noted for his reverence. The earliest stone temple structures, including the main sanctum, likely date to this period. The Navabrahma temples at Alampur (the western gateway to Srisailam) show the architectural style that influenced Srisailam.

title: The Grand Scale Begins
description: The Kakatiya dynasty brought grand scale to the temple. King Prataparudra and his wife visited and performed the Tulabhara ceremony—weighing oneself against gold and jewels to offer to the Lord. The Kakatiyas also improved the treacherous forest paths for pilgrims.

title: Infrastructure and Access
description: The Reddi kings of Kondaveedu made the pilgrimage accessible to common people through major infrastructure projects.
notable: The Viroopaksha Mandapa (Veerasiro Mandapa) is historically linked to Sarvarpana—the extreme Virashaiva practice where devotees offered their own limbs or heads to the deity. This practice was later banned.

title: The Golden Age of Srisailam
description: The Vijayanagara period represents the zenith of Srisailam's architectural and administrative growth. The temple was transformed from a modest shrine into a massive fortified complex capable of withstanding military threats.
notable: Krishnadevaraya visited in 1516 CE after his successful Kalinga campaign, making lavish donations in gratitude for victory.

title: Shivaji's Divine Encounter
description: In 1677, Maratha king Chhatrapati Shivaji visited Srisailam during his southern campaign. Legend states he was so overcome with spiritual ecstasy before Goddess Bhramaramba that he attempted to behead himself as an offering. The Goddess is said to have intervened, blessing him with the Bhavani Khadga (divine sword) instead.
notable: The northern gopuram still bears the name 'Shivaji Gopuram' and features Maratha-influenced architectural elements.

title: Period of Transition
description: Following the fall of Vijayanagara, the region passed through the hands of the Nawabs of Kurnool and later the Nizams of Hyderabad. While direct royal patronage declined, the temple remained active. The British administration placed the temple under a committee of trustees in the 19th century.

title: Modern Revival and the Dam
description: After independence, the temple came under the Andhra Pradesh Endowments Department. The construction of Srisailam Dam (1960s-1980s) transformed the region, vastly improving road access but submerging some minor shrines. The dam created India's largest underground power station.
notable: The ancient Sangameswaram Temple was submerged by the reservoir. It resurfaces briefly each summer when water levels drop.

title: The Copper Plate Revelation
description: In December 2024, the Archaeological Survey of India made a groundbreaking discovery during restoration of the Ghanta Matham near the temple. They unearthed 21 sets of copper plate inscriptions (72 leaves total) and gold coins.
contributions: Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Telugu, and Odia
Records from Vijayanagara, Reddi, and Gajapati dynasties
notable: One inscription from Recharla Lingama Nayaka (1420 CE) describes restoring temple services after disruption by 'Turaka' (Turkish/Bahmani) invasions—rare textual evidence of medieval resilience.
